newsitem.title: FRANCE: SANTER PLEDGES MORE EU JOBS IN 1997.
newsitem.headline: SANTER PLEDGES MORE EU JOBS IN 1997.

text.p: Employment, economic growth and preparation for a single European currency are the main priority for 1997, European Commission President Jacques Santer said on Tuesday.

Presenting the Commission's programme for next year to the European Parliament, Santer added that successful completion of an intergovernmental conference on the EU's future and readiness for EU expansion eastwards were also key aims.
"The main priority...is implementation of the confidence pact for employment," Santer said.
Santer defended his ambitious jobs plans, which were again rejected by EU finance ministers last week, to spend more than $1 billion on trans-European road and rail projects.
"It's not a flash in the pan," Santer said. "Unemployment undermines the confidence of EU citizens. We must restore that confidence."

Santer said the EU's executive was right to insist on strict budgetary spending limits in preparation for a single EU currency on January 1, 1999, which he expected a "significant" number of member states to join.
"Soon we shall see the beneficial effects on employment. That's our true objective. EMU (Economic and Monetary Union) is only a means," he said.
Looking further ahead, Santer said the EU must change the way it works in order to prepare for the next century.
"Enlargement makes this even more necessary," he said, referring to the prospective membership of up to 12 eastern European and Mediterranean countries.
"Maintaining (decision-making) unanimity seems to me inconceivable in a Union of 20 or more members," he said, waarning that otherwise the EU would grind to a halt.
